review.title: Representing and Reasoning with Qualitative Preferences for Compositional Systems
review.abstract: Many applications, e.g., Web service composition, complex system design, team formation, etc., rely on methods for identifying collections of objects or entities satisfying some functional requirement. Among the collections that satisfy the functional requirement, it is often necessary to identify one or more collections that are optimal with respect to user preferences over a set of attributes that describe the non-functional properties of the collection.

metadata.title: Representing and Reasoning with Qualitative Preferences for Compositional Systems

sections.text: We develop a formalism that allows users to express the relative importance of attributes and qualitative preferences over the evaluations of each attribute. We define a dominance relationship that allows us to compare object collections in terms of preferences over the attributes of the objects that make up the collection. We identify some key characteristics of the dominance relationship. In particular, we show that the dominance relationship is a strict suborder when the preference relationships within the attributes represent strict suborders and the relative importance-preference relationship is an interval order. We provide algorithms that use this dominance relationship to identify the set of preferred collections. We show that under certain conditions, the algorithms are guaranteed to return only (solid), all (complete) or at least one (weakly complete) of the preferred collections. We present results from simulation experiments in which the proposed algorithms are most efficient (in terms of the number of) and (in terms of) their solutions.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Many applications require techniques for displaying and reflecting preferences over a set of alternatives. In such constellations, preferences over the alternatives are expressed in relation to a set of attributes that describe the alternatives. Such preferences can be either qualitative or quantitative. However, in many constellations it is more natural to express preferences in qualitative terms (Doyle & Thomason, 1999) and therefore there is a growing interest in formalities for representation and reflection with qualitative preferences (Brafman & Domshlak, 2009) in AI.An important problem in this context has to do with displaying qualitative preferences over multiple attributes and to argue with them in order to find the preferences under a set of c © 2011 AI Access Foundation. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1.1 Illustrative Example
sections.text: Consider the task of designing a study program (POS) for a Master's student in the Faculty of Computer Science. The POS consists of a collection of courses selected from a given repository of available courses and the number of credit hours listed in the table. In this example, each POS can be considered a composition of courses. As a consequence, the requirements for an acceptable Master's program POS (i.e. a feasible composition of courses) are set. The POS should comprise at least 15 credit hours.

sections.heading: 1.2 Problem Statement for the Illustrative Example
sections.text: The problems we try to address in this article for the example above are: • In the face of two courses, namely Pi and Pj, determine whether Pi dominates (i.e., is preferred) in terms of student preferences or vice versa; • In the face of a repository of lectures and an algorithm for calculating a number of acceptable courses, you will find the preferred acceptable courses in terms of the above-mentioned dominance relationships. In the example in Section 1.1, the functional requirements correspond to the three conditions F1 to F3, all of which must be met for a collection of lectures to be an acceptable POS. Area (A), Lecturer (I) and number of credits (C) represent the non-functional attributes, and user preferences towards these attributes are given by the preferences {BA, BA, BA} and I A C. Similar problems can be imagined in several other applications ranging from the assembly of hardware and software components to the general development of a system (such as embedded systems) to the complexity of a system (such as).

sections.heading: 1.3 Contributions
sections.text: In fact, most people are able to determine for themselves how they want to behave.

sections.heading: 1.4 Related Work
sections.text: The closest work related to our work is a work by Binshtok, Brafman, Domshlak and Shimony (2009), which expresses preferences over collections based on the number of objects in the collection that fulfil a desired characteristic (e.g. having at least two political articles and two sports articles when selecting articles for a newspaper publication). In contrast, we develop a formalism that can solve the practicality of the collection as a whole based on the attributes of the objects that make up the collection and algorithms for identifying the preferred collection (s) among those that meet the requirement. We also show how the problems can be solved by solving the formalism based on Binshtok et al. also in our formalism (see Section 7.3.2). In recent years, there has been a lot of work in the database community in evaluating preference queries (e.g. skyline queries), where the preferred subset of tuples is determined based on a result.

sections.heading: 1.5 Organization
sections.text: The rest of the paper is structured as follows: In Section 2, we define a compositional system, discuss the types of preferences that we will consider, and specify the problem in formal terms. In Section 3, we present our preference formalism including the dominance relationship and analyze its properties. In Section 4, we present four algorithms for identifying preferred compositions and discuss their properties. The evidence of the results in this section is provided in Appendix A. In Section 5, we discuss the complexity of our algorithms. In Section 6, we present results of experiments that we have conducted to compare our algorithms in terms of the quality of the solutions produced, performance and efficiency. In Section 7, we summarize our contributions and discuss the related and future work in this area.

sections.heading: 2. Preliminaries
sections.text: We recall some basic characteristics and definitions of binary relationships that we will use in the rest of the article (see Fishburn, 1985, for a comprehensive treatment of the same).

sections.heading: 2.3 Preferences over Non-functional Attributes
sections.text: We now turn to the non-functional aspects of compositional systems. In addition to achieving functionally feasible compositions, users often worry about the non-functional aspects of the compositions, e.g. the reliability of a composite web service. In such cases, among the functionally feasible compositions, users look for the preferred compositions with regard to a number of non-functional attributes describing the components. In order to calculate the most preferred compositions, it is necessary for the user to indicate his preferences over a number of non-functional attributes X.

sections.heading: 2.3.1 Notation
sections.text: The list of notations used in this work is in Table 3.We focus only on strict sub-order preference relationships, i.e. relationships that are both irreflexive and transitive, since transitivity is a natural property of any rational preference relationship (von Neumann & Morgenstern, 1944; French, 1986; Mas-Colell, Whinston, & Green, 1995), and non-reflexivity ensures that preferences are strict. In relation to any strict sub-order relationship of P, we say that two elements u and v are indifferent, referred to as u-P whenever u-Colell, Whinston, & Green, 1995; and non-reflexivity ensures that the preference relationships are strict.

sections.heading: 2.3.2 Representing Multi-Attribute Preferences
sections.text: According to the representation scheme introduced by Boutilier et al. (2004) and Brafman et al. (2006), we model the preferences of the user with respect to several attributes in two forms: (a) preferences of the intra attribute with respect to each non-functional attribute in X and (b) relative meaning across all attributes. (4) We use the terms composition and collection; and component and object interchangeable. Definition 3 (preference of the intra attribute). The preference relationship of the intra attribute with respect to Xi.Definition 4 (relative importance) is a strict subordination (irreflexive and transitive) compared to the possible valuations of an attribute Xi-X.

sections.heading: 3. Preference Formalism
sections.text: In view of a compositional system with a repository of components described by attributes X and preferences ({сi},) over them, we are interested in thinking about preferences over different compositions. Note that, based on preferences and preferences, existing formalities such as TCP networks (Brafman et al., 2006) can be used to select the most preferred components. However, the problem of comparing compositions (as opposed to comparing components) in terms of attribute preferences is complicated by the fact that the evaluation of a composition is a function of the evaluation of its components. Our approach to developing preference formalism is the following. First, in view of a composition and the evaluation of its components in terms of attributes, we obtain the aggregated evaluation of the composition in terms of each attribute. Finally, we build a preference relationship in terms of all qualities on which all compositions are preferred.

sections.heading: 3.1 Aggregating Attribute Valuations across Components
sections.text: In order to think about the evaluations of the components themselves, it is necessary to obtain the evaluation of a composition in relation to each attribute Xi in relation to its components. Remark. In the compositional systems that are considered here, we assume that the evaluation of a composition in relation to its attributes is only a function of the evaluations of its components. In other words, if C = W1 is the evaluation of the components W2. Then VC is a function of only {VW1, VW2,. VWn}. In the most general settings, however, the aggregation functions are not taken into account, in addition to the evaluations of the components themselves, the structural or functional details of a composition.

sections.heading: 3.7 Choosing the Most Preferred Solutions
sections.text: If the preference relationships are fully ordered (e.g. a ranking) over a set of alternative solutions, the rationality of choice suggests ordering the alternatives in relation to the complete preference and choosing the "best" alternative (s), i.e. the one that has the highest ranking. However, if the preference relationship is a strict subordination, e.g. in the case of a set of alternative solutions, not every solution pair (compositions) can be comparable. Therefore, the solution that is most preferred in relation to the preference relationship cannot exist. Therefore, we use the term "non-dominated solution relationship," which is defined as a sequence. Definition 13 (non-dominated composition): The non-dominated group of elements (alternatives or solutions or compositions) of a group C in relation to a (partially ordered) preference (e.g. a set of elements that are defined as a sequence). Definition 13 (non-dominated composition) is the group of elements (alternatives or solutions or compositions) of a group C in relation to a (partially ordered).

sections.heading: 4. Algorithms for Computing the Most Preferred Compositions
sections.text: We now turn to the problem of identifying the preferred subset, i.e. the non-dominated group, out of a series of feasible compositions (which fulfil a given functionality).

sections.heading: 5.3 Complexity of Algorithms
sections.text: Each of the algorithms for the calculation of non-dominated feasible compositions (presented in section 4) uses a functional composition algorithm f to find feasible compositions. Therefore, the complexity analysis of the algorithms must also take into account the complexity of the functional composition algorithm. Remember that algorithms 1, 2 and 3 begin by calculating the set of all feasible compositions in a single setting using a functional composition algorithm as a black box and then finding the most preferred one among them. Instead, algorithm 4 uses a functional composition algorithm which produces the set of feasible compositions by iterative extension of partially feasible compositions. Specifically, it links the execution of the functional composition algorithm with the arrangement of partial solutions taking into account preferences over non-functional attributes.

sections.heading: 5.4 Complexity of Algorithm 1
sections.text: The total complexity for determining the set of all non-dominated practicable compositions is O (fg + cwdomd), where O (d) is the complexity of assessing all pairs of compositions; the first term fg represents line 1 of the algorithm which calculates the set of all practicable compositions, and the term cwdomd corresponds to the calculation of the set of all non-dominated compositions according to the algorithm specified in section 4.1.

sections.heading: 6. Experiments, Results & Analysis
sections.text: We will now describe the design and results of our experiments, which are aimed at comparing the algorithms described in Section 4 with respect to the following attributes: a) the quality of the solutions generated by the algorithms. We measure the quality of the solutions generated by the algorithms as follows: First, among all the preferred solutions that exist for the composition problem, we measure the fraction generated by the algorithm. Second, we measure the fraction of the solutions that are most preferred for the composition problem among all the solutions generated by the algorithm. b) the performance and efficiency of the algorithms. The performance of an algorithm is measured in terms of reaction time (time needed to return the set of solutions), and efficiency is measured in terms of the number of times an algorithm calls the functional composition algorithm.

sections.heading: 6.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: We now describe the data structure used to model the search space of compositions, and the simulation parameters used to generate the compositions in our experiments.

sections.heading: 6.1.3 Implementation of Algorithms
sections.text: Computing Dominance To check whether one rating dominates the other in terms of user preferences (see definition 11), we iterate through all attributes X and check if there is a witness to the dominance to be maintained (see definition 11).Computing the most preferred solutions We implemented the A1, A2, A3, and A4 algorithms in Java. Preliminary experiments with A2 showed that the algorithm was not scaled for large problem cases. In particular, when the number of attributes is large and dominance tests are computationally intensive, A2 was delayed several times for each of the most important attributes due to the calculation of the non-dominated attributes. Therefore, we did not conduct experiments on the samples with A2. However, we were able to conduct experiments with the A3 algorithm, which randomly selects one of the most important attributes and finds the preferred solutions in terms of the intra-attribute preferences of these attributes. In algorithms 1 and Agthmen, we evaluate all of the first steps 12.

sections.heading: 7. Summary and Discussion
sections.text: We now summarize our contributions in this essay.

sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to determine for themselves what they want to do and what they want to do.

sections.heading: 7.3 Related Work
sections.text: Neumann and Morgenstern's groundbreaking work (1944) modelled user preferences using utility functions that mapped possible alternatives to numerical values. More recently, models were developed to represent and argue with quantitative preferences over multiple attributes (Fishburn, 1970a; Keeney & Raiffa, 1993; Bacchus & Grove, 1995; Boutilier, Bacchus, & Brafman, 2001), which were used to solve problems such as identifying preferred tulips resulting from database queries (Agrawal & Wimmers, 2000; Hristidis & Papakonstantinou, 2004; Boutilier, Bacchus, & Brafman, & Brafman).

sections.heading: 7.3.2 Preferences over Collections of Objects
sections.text: Several authors have considered ways to broaden user preferences in order to obtain a ranking of the collections of objects (see Barbera et al., 2004, for a survey).In all of this work, preferences over individual objects in a row are defined as opposed to preferences over the attributes of the objects (see Barbera et al., 2004, for a survey).This scenario can be simulated by our framework by introducing a single attribute whose ratings correspond to objects in the domain. DesJardins et al. (2005) have considered the problem of finding subsets that are optimal in terms of user-specific quantitative preferences by presenting a set of attributes in terms of desired depth, property weight and diversity for each attribute. In contrast, our framework focuses on qualitative preferences. In our setting, preferences, depth preferences that can be assigned to qualitative preferences, can be assigned to relative preferences.

sections.heading: 7.3.3 Database Preference Queries
sections.text: Several authors (Bo � rzso � nyi et al., 2001; Chomicki, 2003; Kiessling & Kostler, 2002; Kiessling, 2002) have explored techniques to integrate user-specific preferences about the results of queries of relationship-related database queries. For example, Chomicki's Frame (2003) includes user preferences about each attribute of a relationship that can be expressed as the first order of logical formulas. Suppose Sq is the set of tuples that correspond to a query q. For each attribute of Xi's of SQi, a subset of tuples that have the most preferred value (s) for Xi, it is determined, and the result of the query q is then given by Sqi. A similar framework for expressing and combining user preferences is presented by Kiessling (2002) and Kiessling and Kostler (2002).

sections.heading: 7.3.4 Planning with Preferences
sections.text: The classic planning problem is to find a sequence of measures that lead a system from an initial state to one of the states that fulfil the goal set by the user. Preferential planning refers to the problem of finding plans that are most favored in terms of a set of user preferences over the plans. Such preferences are usually expressed concise in terms of preferences over the properties satisfied by the plans in the target or intermediate state or over actions or action sequences (i.e. temporal characteristics of the plans). We refer the interested reader to surveys by Baier et al. (2008b) and Bienvenu et al. (2011) for an overview of qualitative and quantitative preference languages used in the preference planning, and various algorithms for calculating the most preferred characteristics of plans. Preferential planning can be considered a problem, the preferred composition in a composite system in which the compositions correspond to the implementable measures and feasible compositions.

sections.heading: 8. Acknowledgments
sections.text: Aspects of this work have been partially supported by NSF grants CNS0709217, CCF0702758, IIS0711356 and CCF1143734. Vasant Honavar's work has been supported by the National Science Foundation during her work at the Foundation. Every opinion, result and conclusion in this article are those of the authors and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation. We are grateful to anonymous critics for a thorough review and Dr. Ronen Brafman for many useful suggestions that have contributed to improving the manuscript.

referenceMentions.context: 3 Contributions We adopt the preference network representation introduced by Brafman et al. (2006) for the specification of qualitative preferences3 over valuations of each attribute as well as the relative importance among the attributes.

(2006), we model the user’s preferences with respect to multiple attributes in two forms: (a) intra-attribute preferences with respect to each non-functional attribute in X , and (b) relative importance over all attributes.

We focus on transitive preferences because many studies have considered transitivity to be a key property of preference relations (von Neumann & Morgenstern, 1944; French, 1986; Mas-Colell et al., 1995)9.

While some studies of human decision making have argued that human preferences are not necessarily transitive (Tversky, 1969), others have offered evidence to the contrary (Regenwetter, Dana, & DavisStober, 2011).

A strict partial order is just irreflexive and transitive; however, the relative importance relation in Definition 12 should in addition satisfy Equation (4), thereby yielding an interval order (Fishburn, 1985).

The algorithm presented by Daskalakis et al. finds the minimal elements; the corresponding algorithm for finding the maximal elements is as follows. Let T0 = ∅. Let the elements of the set S be x1, x2, · · · xn. At step t(≥ 1): • Compare xt to all elements in Tt−1. • If there exists some a ∈ Tt−1 such that a ≻ xt, do nothing. • Otherwise, remove from Tt−1 all elements a such that xt ≻ a and put xt into Tt. On termination, the set Tn contains all the maximal elements in S, i.e., non-dominated subset of S with respect to ≻. We make use of the above algorithm to compute the nondominated (maximal) subsets (namely, Ψ≻(·)), and the original version of the algorithm given in by Daskalakis (2009) to compute the worst-frontiers (minimal subsets).

The seminal work by von Neumann and Morgenstern (1944) models user preferences using utility functions that map the set of possible alternatives to numeric values.
Notable among qualitative frameworks for preferences are preference networks (Boutilier et al., 2004; Brafman et al., 2006) that deal with qualitative and conditional preferences.
Notable among qualitative frameworks for preferences are preference networks (Boutilier et al., 2004; Brafman et al., 2006) that deal with qualitative and conditional preferences.

A class of preference networks, namely Tradeoff-enhanced Conditional Preference networks (TCP-nets) (Brafman et al., 2006) are closely related to our work, and we now proceed to discuss where our framework departs from and adds to the existing TCP-net framework.

Several authors have considered ways to extend user preferences to obtain a ranking of collections of objects (see Barbera et al., 2004, for a survey). In all these works, preferences are specified over individual objects in a set as opposed to preferences over valuations of the attributes of the objects. The preferences over objects are in turn used to reason about preferences over collections of those objects. This scenario can be simulated by our framework, by introducing a single attribute whose valuations correspond to objects in the domain. DesJardins et al. (2005) have considered the problem of finding subsets that are optimal with respect to user specified quantitative preferences over a set of attributes in terms of the desired depth, feature weight and diversity for each attribute.
More recently, Binshtok et al. (2009) have presented a language for specification of preferences over sets of objects.

More recently, Binshtok et al. (2009) have presented a language for specification of preferences over sets of objects. This framework, in addition to intra-attribute and relative importance preferences over attributes, allows users to express preferences over the number (|φ|) of elements in a set that satisfy a desired property φ. The preference language in this case allows statements such as “Si : |φ| REL n” (number of elements in the preferred set with property φ should be REL n), “Sj : |φ| REL |ψ|” (number of elements in the preferred set with property φ should be REL number of elements in the preferred set with property ψ), etc., where REL is one of the arithmetic operators >,<,=,≥,≤ and n is an integer. In addition, there can be relative importance between the various preference statements such as “Si is more important than Sj” as well as external cardinality constraints such as a bound on the number of elements in the preferred set. Our formalism can accommodate such preference statements, by representing each preference statement Si as a new binary valued attribute in the compositional system. For example, preference statements Si : |φ| ≥ n and Sj : |φ| ≤ |ψ| can be represented in our formalism by creating new binary attributes Xi and Xj with intra-attribute preferences 1 ≻i 0 and 1 ≻j 0 respectively. The relative importance statements such as “Si is more important than Sj” can then be directly mapped to Xi ⊲ Xj . Any external cardinality constraints on the size of the preferred set can be encoded in our setting by functional requirements, so as to restrict the feasible solutions to only those that satisfy the cardinality constraints. Consider the example discussed by Binshtok et al. (2009), with preferences over senate members described by attributes: Party affiliation (Republican, Democrat ), Views (liberal, conservative, ultra conservative), and Experience (experienced, inexperienced).

Having defined the above aggregation function and comparison relation for each new attribute, any dominance relation can be adopted to compare compositions (arbitrary subsets) with respect to all attributes including the dominance relation used by Binshtok et al. (2009). In contrast to the framework of Binshtok et al.

Having defined the above aggregation function and comparison relation for each new attribute, any dominance relation can be adopted to compare compositions (arbitrary subsets) with respect to all attributes including the dominance relation used by Binshtok et al. (2009). In contrast to the framework of Binshtok et al., (2009) our formalism focuses on collections of objects that satisfy some desired criteria, rather than arbitrary subsets.

metadata.abstractText: Many applications, e.g., Web service composition, complex system design, team formation, etc., rely on methods for identifying collections of objects or entities satisfying some functional requirement. Among the collections that satisfy the functional requirement, it is often necessary to identify one or more collections that are optimal with respect to user preferences over a set of attributes that describe the non-functional properties of the collection. We develop a formalism that lets users express the relative importance among attributes and qualitative preferences over the valuations of each attribute. We define a dominance relation that allows us to compare collections of objects in terms of preferences over attributes of the objects that make up the collection. We establish some key properties of the dominance relation. In particular, we show that the dominance relation is a strict partial order when the intra-attribute preference relations are strict partial orders and the relative importance preference relation is an interval order. We provide algorithms that use this dominance relation to identify the set of most preferred collections. We show that under certain conditions, the algorithms are guaranteed to return only (sound), all (complete), or at least one (weakly complete) of the most preferred collections. We present results of simulation experiments comparing the proposed algorithms with respect to (a) the quality of solutions (number of most preferred solutions) produced by the algorithms, and (b) their performance and efficiency. We also explore some interesting conjectures suggested by the results of our experiments that relate the properties of the user preferences, the dominance relation, and the algorithms.
